THE STRANGE REALITY OF BEING A $TSLA SHAREHOLDER IN 2025

It‚Äôs been hard to explain what it feels like holding Tesla right now. I haven‚Äôt lost conviction in what the company is trying to do -- I still believe it‚Äôs one of the most important players in energy, autonomy, and robotics -- but I‚Äôd be lying if I said the noise around it hasn‚Äôt made me hesitate.

I haven‚Äôt added to the position in a while. Not because I think the company has lost its way, but because the surrounding narrative has become so chaotic it‚Äôs hard to think clearly about the actual innovation happening inside the business. And when that happens -- when the signal gets drowned out by everything else -- I‚Äôve learned it‚Äôs usually a good time to step back and size down.

I get why Elon‚Äôs making the moves he‚Äôs making. It‚Äôs not random. It‚Äôs strategic. He‚Äôs targeting leverage points that most people overlook -- using the same kind of systems thinking that built Tesla and SpaceX in the first place. But I didn‚Äôt invest in a political movement. I invested in a company that was changing the way the world moves and stores energy. And it‚Äôs exhausting watching that mission get sidelined in headlines that have nothing to do with autonomous driving or Optimus or Dojo or battery innovation.

There‚Äôs a version of the next two years where Tesla stays laser-focused and delivers. That version is still very much possible. But there‚Äôs also a version where politics and media drama keep pulling the narrative off-course. And I don‚Äôt know how to price that, other than to stay underexposed and patient.

A lot of what‚Äôs happening right now has nothing to do with Tesla‚Äôs actual mission -- it‚Äôs a context problem, not a fundamentals one. Elon‚Äôs public profile is so polarizing that even the most transformative work gets overshadowed. The criticisms -- especially from figures like President Trump -- aren‚Äôt rooted in the tech, they‚Äôre political theater. And unfortunately, in an attention economy, the noise often wins.

But the truth is, Tesla is quietly building the neural infrastructure for autonomous mobility and intelligent robotics at global scale. This isn‚Äôt about selling cars -- it‚Äôs about training fleets, coordinating edge inference, and building a vertically integrated AI network that spans vehicles, humanoids, and energy systems. While the narrative drifts, the real work continues -- and it‚Äôs decades ahead of where the rest of the world is even looking. But you‚Äôd never know it with the way people talk. The conversation‚Äôs stuck in the mud -- personality politics, subsidy arguments, clickbait headlines -- all while Tesla is quietly building the AI network for mobility and robotics. Real autonomy. Real humanoid deployment. Real-time decision loops at the edge. That‚Äôs the game. And no one‚Äôs paying attention.

I still back the mission. Always have. But belief doesn‚Äôt mean blind exposure. When a story gets this noisy -- when execution starts competing with narrative distortion -- I pull back. Not because the fundamentals aren‚Äôt there, but because position sizing is how you survive long enough to be right.

Cautiously optimistic  ü§ûüèº

Wild how much hate retail-heavy names like $PLTR, $HIMS, $OSCR, $AMD, $RKLB, $IONQ, $HOOD, $SOFI & $OKLO still get.

I get it -- it‚Äôs unsettling watching so-called ‚Äúdumb money‚Äù outperform Wall Street over the past couple years. But shouldn‚Äôt we be rooting for that? For the democratization of investing?

Most of the pushback sounds like envy -- from people who missed the boat and can‚Äôt stand watching others win. And I‚Äôve missed plenty too. I didn‚Äôt catch $HIMS, $HOOD or $SOFI early either. But even if you did miss it, you should still root for this shift. 

Tearing down institutional walls is overdue -- and it‚Äôs happening whether they like it or not.
$TSLA ELON MUSK FILES FEC PAPERWORK -- THE AMERICA PARTY IS HAPPENING

You might be asking -- why does $QQQ keep catching a bid when most of their PEG ratios are above 2.0?

The market‚Äôs not just paying for current growth. It‚Äôs pricing in future margin expansion driven by AI -- leaner OpEx, workforce reduction & a productivity boom that could re-rate earnings far above current estimates.

PEG RATIO IS THE SLEEPER VALUATION METRIC MOST IGNORE

Peter Lynch loved it for a reason.
Under 1 = mispriced growth. Over 2 = danger zone.
